Comments: No disclosure found. According to Section 10.6.1 of its Code of Business Conduct and Ethics (Sources 7, 8), Ooredoo Qatar has a whistleblower policy. However, since the company does not make any public commitments to protecting users' freedom of expression, nor does it discuss freedom of expression issues in its Business Code of Conduct, no credit is given.

No disclosure found. According to Section 10.6.1 of its Code of Business Conduct and Ethics (Sources 7, 8), Ooredoo Qatar has a whistleblower policy. However, there is no reference to any guidelines or principles for protecting users' privacy nor has the company made other general commitments to protecting users'  privacy rights. Therefore no credit is awarded.

Comments: Yes. Ooredoo Qatar's terms of service for Fiber Home service (Sources 29, 30) can be accessed by clicking on Terms and Conditions at the bottom of the Fiber Home service page. Also Ooredoo Qatar's terms of service (Sources 3, 4), which applies to all telecommunications services, can be accessed by clicking on General Terms and Conditions at the bottom of the homepage.

Yes. Ooredoo Qatar's terms of service  (Sources 3, 4) can be accessed by clicking on General Terms and Conditions at the bottom of the homepage. The terms apply to "any telecommunications services..., as well as any related software, content, or equipment" provided by the company.

Partial. Ooredoo Qatar's terms of service for Fiber Home service (Sources 29, 30) are only available in English; when you visit the Arabic interface of Fiber Home page and click on Terms and Conditions you still get the English version. However, the general Ooredoo Qatar's terms of service (Source 3, 4) are available in both Arabic and English, therefore partial credit is given.
Yes. Ooredoo Qatar's terms of service (Sources 3, 4) are available in both Arabic and English.
Yes. Ooredoo Qatar's terms of service (Sources 3, 4) are available in both Arabic and English.

Yes. The fixed-line broadband terms of service (Sources 29, 30) and the general Ooredoo Qatar terms of service (Sources 3, 4) are written in a clear and understandable manner, and the font size makes them easy to read. In addition, the company uses section headers and short sentences and paragraphs that make it easy for users to find information.

Partial.The Ooredoo Qatar terms of service state the following (Sources 3, 4): " Ooredoo may, from time to time and consistent with its obligations under the Applicable Regulatory Framework and the approval of ictQATAR, if required, (a) modify the fees and charges contained in the Service Tariff or (b) Make changes to these General Terms and Conditions with reasonable notice to you." The company doesn't clarify what is a "reasonable notice." The fixed-line broadband terms of service for Ooredoo Qatar states that (Sources 29, 30): "We may change this Agreement and any Services at any time. Changes will be posted on our Website. Please check this regularly for updates." None of these sources disclose clearly that the company will notify users about changes to its terms, hence partial credit is given.

Yes. In the Disconnection of Services part of Fiber Home Terms and Conditions (Sources 29, 30), Ooredoo Qatar says that “we can bar, re-direct or restrict your use of any or all of the Services or disconnect your connection if you make abusive, offensive, malicious or nuisance calls or communications, or use any of our Services in an offensive way; you are abusive or offensive to us, our dealers or agents, or any other person; o we suspect you of using the services for any illegal or fraudulent activity”.

Yes. In section 12 of the terms of service (Sources 3, 4), Ooredoo Qatar lists a number of activities it does not permit. This includes "to send, knowingly receive, upload, download, or use any material that is offensive, abusive, defamatory obscene, menacing or illegal", "to violate any copyright or other intellectual property rights of any person", and "to access or to attempt to access any computer system or network or any private information resources unlawfully, for unlawful purposes or without the consent of the holder of such information or resources".

Yes. In the Disconnection of Services part of Fiber Home Terms and Conditions (Sources 29, 30), Ooredoo Qatar says that “we can bar, re-direct or restrict your use of any or all of the Services or disconnect your connection if you make abusive, offensive, malicious or nuisance calls or communications, or use any of our Services in an offensive way; you are abusive or offensive to us, our dealers or agents, or any other person; o we suspect you of using the services for any illegal or fraudulent activity”.

Yes. In section 16 of the general terms of service (Sources 3, 4), the company clarifies the reasons it mays suspend, restrict or disconnect the service: "16.1 If the Subscriber exceeds his applicable credit limit, or fails to pay his bill or other Ooredoo charges; 16.2 If the Subscriber breaches any of the Service conditions, in particular, Article 12 (Use of Ooredoo Services and Equipment); 16.3 if Ooredoo ceases to provide the Service to the public for any reason, taking into account its relevant obligations under the Applicable Regulatory Framework; or 16.4 if any competent authority prohibits the provision of the Service in Qatar."

Yes. No disclosure found. However, the company does not disclose how it may become aware of suspicious activity.

Partial. The company does not clearly explain why it may shut down its service. Article 15 of the general terms of service (Sources 3, 4) state that the company "may occasionally need to interrupt the Service for scheduled required maintenance, test procedures or other technical work, including network upgrades. Ooredoo will endeavour to notify you 24 hours in advance of such disruption where possible." However, in sections 16.3 and 16.4, the company states it may "cease to provide the Service to the public for any reason, taking into account its relevant obligations under the Applicable Regulatory Framework; or if any competent authority prohibits the provision of the Service in Qatar."  Partial. In the Planned & Unplanned Outages part of Fireb Home Terms and Conditions (Sources 29, 30), the company states that "The Customer acknowledges that from time to time Ooredoo may carry out maintenance or testing of its network." And "the Customer acknowledges that there may be unplanned outages which may cause disruption to the Service." Given that the company does not clearly explain all circumstances under which it may shut down services, it receives partial credit.

Yes. Ooredoo required users of its prepaid mobile service to verify their identities with government-issued IDs. The Hala prepaid service website (Sources 9, 10) states the following: "Buy a Hala package from our eShop online, or pop in at any of our shops or authorised dealers and bring a copy of your national ID, passport or your residence permit." Users are also required to submit a passport or national ID number to create a "My Ooredoo" account (Sources 31, 32).

No disclosure found. In Section 10.3.7.3 of Ooredoo Qatar's Code of Business Conduct and Ethics (Sources 7, 8), the company states the following: "All personnel shall maintain the confidentiality of information entrusted to them by the Company or its customers, except when disclosure is authorized or legally mandated." Section 10.3.7.4 further prohibits employees from using "their positions in the Company to make any unauthorized intrusion into the privacy of the communication of any personnel or customers." However, Ooredoo Qatar does not explicitly disclose if it has systems in place to limit and monitor employee access to user information.
